docs.lead_paragraph: Because efforts to stop global warming may fail, one way to handle the financial losses is to share the long-term risks.
docs.abstract: The Upshot; Robert J Shiller Economic View column argues that insurance will play an essential role as effects of climate change worsen, helping to share burden of devastation that is concentrated in coastal and other specific areas; holds that private insurance companies will require government support and significant incentives in order to take on such grand-scale issues.
docs.snippet: Because efforts to stop global warming may fail, one way to handle the financial losses is to share the long-term risks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in several states have passed legislation to address concerns about potential security risks involving workers hired to help people apply for health care insurance under the Affordable Care Act. There's no sign, however, that the enrollment assistants, even those with criminal records, have misused consumers' personal information.

headline.main: 5 Things to Know About Health Navigator Security
headline.print_headline: 5 Things to Know About Health Navigator Security

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican lawmakers around the country are adding criminal background checks or licensing requirements for workers hired to help people enroll in health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, taking aim at perceived security risks involving customers' personal information.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama celebrated when sign-ups for his health care law topped 8 million, far exceeding expectations after a slipshod launch. Most Americans, however, remain unimpressed.

headline.main: Poll: Health Care Law Still Fails to Impress

docs.lead_paragraph: Veterans must get the medical care they need.

headline.main: Why I Blew the Whistle on the V.A.
headline.print_headline: Why I Blew the Whistle on the V.A.

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Dr Sam Foote explains his reasons for becoming a whistle-blower after 24 years as a physician at the Phoenix Veterans Affairs hospital, helping to bring scheduling scandal to light; says it is apparent that scandal is symptom of much more serious disease--a mismatch between the mission of the Veterans Affairs Dept and its resources.
docs.snippet: Veterans must get the medical care they need.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fraudsters leverage older people’s sense of responsibility, posing as relatives in need of help, or law enforcement officials.

headline.main: Phone Swindlers Tap Into Fear and a Sense of Duty
headline.print_headline: Phone Swindlers Tap Into Fear and a Sense of Duty

docs.abstract: Phone swindlers prey on an elderly victim's sense of duty, presenting scams that catch them unaware and vulnerable; many seniors, who are targeted because of their retirement nest egg, do not report crimes out of embarrassment.
docs.snippet: Fraudsters leverage older people’s sense of responsibility, posing as relatives in need of help, or law enforcement officials.

docs.lead_paragraph: Modern antiretroviral drugs could alter the epidemic much as birth control changed the culture in the ’60s.

headline.main: Are We Ready for H.I.V.’s Sexual Revolution?
headline.print_headline: Are We Ready for H.I.V.’s Sexual Revolution?

docs.abstract: News analysis; decision by Food and Drug Administration to approve drug Truvada for prevention of HIV has triggered backlash among some who believe it will lead to unsafe sex among gay men and increase rates of other sexually transmitted diseases; if preventive use of drug does become accepted, it will show that modern antiretroviral drugs are phenomenally potent weapons that could be key to finally shrinking the epidemic.
docs.snippet: Modern antiretroviral drugs could alter the epidemic much as birth control changed the culture in the ’60s.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell wants to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but he would not say Friday what that would mean for the 413,000 Kentuckians who have health insurance through the state's health care exchange.

headline.main: McConnell: Ky. Exchange Unconnected to Health Law
headline.print_headline: McConnell: Ky. Exchange Unconnected to Health Law

docs.lead_paragraph: A former senior Bolivian anti-corruption official convicted of trying to extort $30,000 from a Bolivian businessman in Miami was sentenced on Friday to more than three years in a U.S. federal prison.

headline.main: Bolivian Anti-Graft Cop Sent to Prison in U.S. Extortion Case
headline.print_headline: Bolivian Anti-Graft Cop Sent to Prison in U.S. Extortion Case
